api.desc: Scripts can have parameters defined in the level XML file. These serve as input to a specific instance of the script and can be used to configure various options and parameters of the script. While these parameters can be read at any time in the script, it's recommended to copy them to a global variable in or outside the init function.

functions.name: GetIntParam

return.name: value
return.desc: Parameter value

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Retrieve blinkcount parameter, or set to 5 if omitted
parameterBlinkCount = GetIntParam("blinkcount", 5)

functions.name: GetFloatParam

return.name: value
return.desc: Parameter value

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Retrieve speed parameter, or set to 10.0 if omitted
parameterSpeed = GetFloatParam("speed", 10.0)

functions.name: GetBoolParam

return.name: value
return.desc: Parameter value

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Retrieve playsound parameter, or false if omitted
parameterPlaySound = GetBoolParam("playsound", false)

functions.name: GetStringParam

return.name: value
return.desc: Parameter value

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Retrieve mode parameter, or "idle" if omitted
parameterMode = GetSrtingParam("mode", "idle")

api.desc: General functions that control the operation and flow of the script.

functions.name: GetVersion

return.name: version
return.desc: Dot separated string of current version of the game

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local v = GetVersion()
--v is "0.5.0"

functions.name: HasVersion

return.name: match
return.desc: True if current version is at least provided one

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if HasVersion("0.6.0") then
	--conditional code that only works on 0.6.0 or above
else
	--legacy code that works on earlier versions
end

functions.name: GetTime

return.name: time
return.desc: The time in seconds since level was started

functions.info:
Returns running time of this script. If called from update, this returns
the simulated time, otherwise it returns wall time.
functions.example: local t = GetTime()

functions.name: GetTimeStep

return.name: dt
return.desc: The timestep in seconds

functions.info:
Returns timestep of the last frame. If called from update, this returns
the simulation time step, which is always one 60th of a second (0.0166667).
If called from tick or draw it returns the actual time since last frame.
functions.example: local dt = GetTimeStep()

functions.name: InputLastPressedKey

return.name: name
return.desc: Name of last pressed key, empty if no key is pressed

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: name = InputLastPressedKey()

functions.name: InputPressed

return.name: pressed
return.desc: True if input was pressed during last frame

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if InputPressed("interact") then
	...
end

functions.name: InputReleased

return.name: pressed
return.desc: True if input was released during last frame

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if InputReleased("interact") then
	...
end

functions.name: InputDown

return.name: pressed
return.desc: True if input is currently held down

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if InputDown("interact") then
...
end

functions.name: InputValue

return.name: value
return.desc: Depends on input type

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: scrollPos = scrollPos + InputValue("mousewheel")

functions.name: SetValue

arguments.name: variable
arguments.desc: Name of number variable in the global context

functions.info:
Set value of a number variable in the global context with an optional transition.
If a transition is provided the value will animate from current value to the new value during the transition time.
Transition can be one of the following:

Transition  Description
linear	 Linear transitioncosine	 Slow at beginning and endeasein	 Slow at beginningeaseout	 Slow at endbounce	 Bounce and overshoot new value
functions.example:
myValue = 0
SetValue("myValue", 1, "linear", 0.5)

This will change the value of myValue from 0 to 1 in a linear fasion over 0.5 seconds

functions.name: PauseMenuButton

return.name: clicked
return.desc: True if clicked, false otherwise

functions.info:
Calling this function will add a button on the bottom bar or in the main pause menu (center of the screen) when the game is paused. 
A primary button will be placed in the main pause menu if this function is called from a playable mod. There can be only one primary button.
Use this as a way to bring up mod settings or other user interfaces while the game is running. 
Call this function every frame from the tick function for as long as the pause menu button
should still be visible.
functions.example:
function tick()

    -- Primary button will be placed in the main pause menu
	if PauseMenuButton("Back to Hub", true) then
		StartLevel("hub", "MOD/hub.xml")
	end
	
	-- Button will be placed in the bottom bar of the pause menu
	if PauseMenuButton("MyMod Settings") then
		visible = true
	end
end

function draw()
	if visible then
		UiMakeInteractive()
		...
	end
end

functions.name: StartLevel

arguments.name: layers
arguments.desc: Active layers. Default is no layers.

arguments.name: passThrough
arguments.desc: If set, loading screen will have no text and music will keep playing

functions.info: Start a level
functions.example:
--Start level with no active layers
StartLevel("level1", "MOD/level1.xml")

--Start level with two layers
StartLevel("level1", "MOD/level1.xml", "vehicles targets")

functions.name: SetPaused

arguments.name: paused
arguments.desc: True if game should be paused

functions.info: Set paused state of the game
functions.example:
--Pause game and bring up pause menu on HUD
SetPaused(true)

functions.name: Restart
functions.info: Restart level
functions.example:
if shouldRestart then
Restart()
end

functions.name: Menu
functions.info: Go to main menu
functions.example:
if shouldExitLevel then
Menu()
end

api.desc:
The Teardown engine uses a global key/value-pair registry that scripts can read and write. The engine exposes a lot of internal information through the registry, but it can also be used as way for scripts to communicate with each other.
The registry is a hierarchical node structure and can store a value in each node (parent nodes can also have a value). The values can be of type floating point number, integer, boolean or string, but all types are automatically converted if another type is requested. Some registry nodes are reserved and used for special purposes.
Registry node names may only contain the characters a-z, numbers 0-9, dot, dash and underscore.

functions.name: ClearKey
functions.info: Remove registry node, including all child nodes.
functions.example:
--If the registry looks like this:
--	score
--		levels
--			level1 = 5
--			level2 = 4

ClearKey("score.levels")

--Afterwards, the registry will look like this:
--	score

functions.name: ListKeys

return.name: children
return.desc: Indexed table of strings with child keys

functions.info: List all child keys of a registry node.
functions.example:
--If the registry looks like this:
--	score
--		levels
--			level1 = 5
--			level2 = 4

local list = ListKeys("score.levels")
for i=1, #list do
	print(list[i])
end

--This will output:
--level1
--level2

functions.name: HasKey

return.name: exists
return.desc: True if key exists

functions.info: Returns true if the registry contains a certain key
functions.example: local foo = HasKey("score.levels")

functions.name: SetInt
functions.info: No Description
functions.example: SetInt("score.levels.level1", 4)

functions.name: GetInt

return.name: value
return.desc: Integer value of registry node or zero if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local a = GetInt("score.levels.level1")

functions.name: SetFloat
functions.info: No Description
functions.example: SetFloat("level.time", 22.3)

functions.name: GetFloat

return.name: value
return.desc: Float value of registry node or zero if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local time = GetFloat("level.time")

functions.name: SetBool
functions.info: No Description
functions.example: SetBool("level.robots.enabled", true)

functions.name: GetBool

return.name: value
return.desc: Boolean value of registry node or false if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local isRobotsEnabled = GetBool("level.robots.enabled")

functions.name: SetString
functions.info: No Description
functions.example: SetString("level.name", "foo")

functions.name: GetString

return.name: value
return.desc: String value of registry node or "" if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local name = GetString("level.name")

api.desc: Vector math is used in Teardown scripts to represent 3D positions, directions, rotations and transforms. The base types are vectors, quaternions and transforms. Vectors and quaternions are indexed tables with three and four components. Transforms are tables consisting of one vector (pos) and one quaternion (rot)

functions.name: Vec

return.name: vec
return.desc: New vector

functions.info:
Create new vector and optionally initializes it to the provided values.
A Vec is equivalent to a regular lua table with three numbers.

functions.name: VecCopy

return.name: new
return.desc: Copy of org vector

functions.info:
Vectors should never be assigned like regular numbers. Since they are
implemented with lua tables assignment means two references pointing to
the same data. Use this function instead.
functions.example:
--Do this to assign a vector
local right1 = Vec(1, 2, 3)
local right2 = VecCopy(right1)

--Never do this unless you REALLY know what you're doing
local wrong1 = Vec(1, 2, 3)
local wrong2 = wrong1

functions.name: VecLength

return.name: length
return.desc: Length (magnitude) of the vector

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local v = Vec(1,1,0)
local l = VecLength(v)

--l now equals 1.41421356

functions.name: VecNormalize

return.name: norm
return.desc: A vector of length 1.0

functions.info: If the input vector is of zero length, the function returns {0,0,1}

functions.name: VecScale

return.name: norm
return.desc: A scaled version of input vector

functions.info: No Description

functions.name: VecAdd

return.name: c
return.desc: New vector with sum of a and b

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local a = Vec(1,2,3)
local b = Vec(3,0,0)
local c = VecAdd(a, b)

--c now equals {4,2,3}

functions.name: VecSub

return.name: c
return.desc: New vector representing a-b

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local a = Vec(1,2,3)
local b = Vec(3,0,0)
local c = VecSub(a, b)

--c now equals {-2,2,3}

functions.name: VecDot

return.name: c
return.desc: Dot product of a and b

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local a = Vec(1,2,3)
local b = Vec(3,1,0)
local c = VecDot(a, b)

--c now equals 5

functions.name: VecCross

return.name: c
return.desc: Cross product of a and b (also called vector product)

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local a = Vec(1,0,0)
local b = Vec(0,1,0)
local c = VecCross(a, b)

--c now equals {0,0,1}

functions.name: VecLerp

return.name: c
return.desc: Linearly interpolated vector between a and b, using t

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local a = Vec(2,0,0)
local b = Vec(0,4,2)
local t = 0.5

--These two are equivalent
local c1 = VecLerp(a, b, t)
lcoal c2 = VecAdd(VecScale(a, 1-t), VecScale(b, t))

--c1 and c2 now equals {1, 2, 1}

functions.name: Quat

return.name: quat
return.desc: New quaternion

functions.info:
Create new quaternion and optionally initializes it to the provided values.
Do not attempt to initialize a quaternion with raw values unless you know
what you are doing. Use QuatEuler or QuatAxisAngle instead.
If no arguments are given, a unit quaternion will be created: {0, 0, 0, 1}.
A quaternion is equivalent to a regular lua table with four numbers.

functions.name: QuatCopy

return.name: new
return.desc: Copy of org quaternion

functions.info:
Quaternions should never be assigned like regular numbers. Since they are
implemented with lua tables assignment means two references pointing to
the same data. Use this function instead.
functions.example:
--Do this to assign a quaternion
local right1 = QuatEuler(0, 90, 0)
local right2 = QuatCopy(right1)

--Never do this unless you REALLY know what you're doing
local wrong1 = QuatEuler(0, 90, 0)
local wrong2 = wrong1

functions.name: QuatAxisAngle

return.name: quat
return.desc: New quaternion

functions.info: Create a quaternion representing a rotation around a specific axis
functions.example:
--Create quaternion representing rotation 30 degrees around Y axis
local q = QuatAxisAngle(Vec(0,1,0), 30)

functions.name: QuatEuler

arguments.name: x
arguments.desc: Angle around X axis in degrees, sometimes also called roll or bank

arguments.name: y
arguments.desc: Angle around Y axis in degrees, sometimes also called yaw or heading

arguments.name: z
arguments.desc: Angle around Z axis in degrees, sometimes also called pitch or attitude

return.name: quat
return.desc: New quaternion

functions.info:
Create quaternion using euler angle notation. The order of applied rotations uses the
"NASA standard aeroplane" model:
Rotation around Y axis (yaw or heading)
Rotation around Z axis (pitch or attitude)
Rotation around X axis (roll or bank)
functions.example:
--Create quaternion representing rotation 30 degrees around Y axis and 25 degrees around Z axis
local q = QuatEuler(0, 30, 25)

functions.name: GetQuatEuler

return.name: x
return.desc: Angle around X axis in degrees, sometimes also called roll or bank

return.name: y
return.desc: Angle around Y axis in degrees, sometimes also called yaw or heading

return.name: z
return.desc: Angle around Z axis in degrees, sometimes also called pitch or attitude

functions.info:
Return euler angles from quaternion. The order of rotations uses the "NASA standard aeroplane" model:
Rotation around Y axis (yaw or heading)
Rotation around Z axis (pitch or attitude)
Rotation around X axis (roll or bank)
functions.example:
--Return euler angles from quaternion q
rx, ry, rz = GetQuatEuler(q)

functions.name: QuatLookAt

arguments.name: target
arguments.desc: Vector representing the point to look at

return.name: quat
return.desc: New quaternion

functions.info:
Create a quaternion pointing the negative Z axis (forward) towards
a specific point, keeping the Y axis upwards. This is very useful
for creating camera transforms.
functions.example:
local eye = Vec(0, 10, 0)
local target = Vec(0, 1, 5)
local rot = QuatLookAt(eye, target)
SetCameraTransform(Transform(eye, rot))

functions.name: QuatSlerp

return.name: c
return.desc: New quaternion

functions.info:
Spherical, linear interpolation between a and b, using t. This is
very useful for animating between two rotations.
functions.example:
local a = QuatEuler(0, 10, 0)
local b = QuatEuler(0, 0, 45)

--Create quaternion half way between a and b
local q = QuatSlerp(a, b, 0.5)

functions.name: QuatRotateQuat

return.name: c
return.desc: New quaternion

functions.info:
Rotate one quaternion with another quaternion. This is mathematically
equivalent to c = a * b using quaternion multiplication.
functions.example:
local a = QuatEuler(0, 10, 0)
local b = QuatEuler(0, 0, 45)
local q = QuatRotateQuat(a, b)

--q now represents a rotation first 10 degrees around
--the Y axis and then 45 degrees around the Z axis.

functions.name: QuatRotateVec

return.name: vec
return.desc: Rotated vector

functions.info: Rotate a vector by a quaternion
functions.example:
local q = QuatEuler(0, 10, 0)
local v = Vec(1, 0, 0)
local r = QuatRotateVec(q, v)

--r is now vector a rotated 10 degrees around the Y axis

functions.name: Transform

return.name: transform
return.desc: New transform

functions.info:
A transform is a regular lua table with two entries: pos and rot,
a vector and quaternion representing transform position and rotation.
functions.example:
--Create transform located at {0, 0, 0} with no rotation
local t1 = Transform()

--Create transform located at {10, 0, 0} with no rotation
local t2 = Transform(Vec(10, 0,0))

--Create transform located at {10, 0, 0}, rotated 45 degrees around Y axis
local t2 = Transform(Vec(10, 0,0), QuatEuler(0, 45, 0))

functions.name: TransformCopy

return.name: new
return.desc: Copy of org transform

functions.info:
Transforms should never be assigned like regular numbers. Since they are
implemented with lua tables assignment means two references pointing to
the same data. Use this function instead.
functions.example:
--Do this to assign a quaternion
local right1 = Transform(Vec(1,0,0), QuatEuler(0, 90, 0))
local right2 = TransformCopy(right1)

--Never do this unless you REALLY know what you're doing
local wrong1 = Transform(Vec(1,0,0), QuatEuler(0, 90, 0))
local wrong2 = wrong1

functions.name: TransformToParentTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: New transform

functions.info:
Transform child transform out of the parent transform.
This is the opposite of TransformToLocalTransform.
functions.example:
local b = GetBodyTransform(body)
local s = GetShapeLocalTransform(shape)

--b represents the location of body in world space
--s represents the location of shape in body space

local w = TransformToParentTransform(b, s)

--w now represents the location of shape in world space

functions.name: TransformToLocalTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: New transform

functions.info:
Transform one transform into the local space of another transform.
This is the opposite of TransformToParentTransform.
functions.example:
local b = GetBodyTransform(body)
local w = GetShapeWorldTransform(shape)

--b represents the location of body in world space
--w represents the location of shape in world space

local s = TransformToLocalTransform(b, w)

--s now represents the location of shape in body space.

functions.name: TransformToParentVec

return.name: r
return.desc: Transformed vector

functions.info: Transfom vector v out of transform t only considering rotation.
functions.example:
local t = GetBodyTransform(body)
local localUp = Vec(0, 1, 0)
local up = TransformToParentVec(t, localUp)

--up now represents the local body up direction in world space

functions.name: TransformToLocalVec

return.name: r
return.desc: Transformed vector

functions.info: Transfom vector v into transform t only considering rotation.
functions.example:
local t = GetBodyTransform(body)
local worldUp = Vec(0, 1, 0)
local up = TransformToLocalVec(t, worldUp)

--up now represents the world up direction in local body space

functions.name: TransformToParentPoint

return.name: r
return.desc: Transformed position

functions.info: Transfom position p out of transform t.
functions.example:
local t = GetBodyTransform(body)
local bodyPoint = Vec(0, 0, -1)
local p = TransformToParentPoint(t, bodyPoint)

--p now represents the local body point {0, 0, -1 } in world space

functions.name: TransformToLocalPoint

return.name: r
return.desc: Transformed position

functions.info: Transfom position p into transform t.
functions.example:
local t = GetBodyTransform(body)
local worldOrigo = Vec(0, 0, 0)
local p = TransformToLocalPoint(t, worldOrigo)

--p now represents the position of world origo in local body space

api.desc: An Entity is the basis of most objects in the Teardown engine (bodies, shapes, lights, locations, etc). All entities can have tags, which is a way to store custom properties on entities for scripting purposes. Some tags are also reserved for engine use. See documentation for details.

functions.name: SetTag
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Add "special" tag to an entity
SetTag(handle, "special")

--Add "team" tag to an entity and give it value "red"
SetTag(handle, "team", "red")

functions.name: RemoveTag
functions.info: Remove tag from an entity. If the tag had a value it is removed too.
functions.example: RemoveTag(handle, "special")

functions.name: HasTag

return.name: exists
return.desc: Returns true if entity has tag

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
SetTag(handle, "special")
local hasSpecial = HasTag(handle, "special") 
-- hasSpecial will be true

functions.name: GetTagValue

return.name: value
return.desc: Returns the tag value, if any. Empty string otherwise.

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
SetTag(handle, "special")
value = GetTagValue(handle, "special")
-- value will be ""

SetTag(handle, "special", "foo")
value = GetTagValue(handle, "special")
-- value will be "foo"

functions.name: GetDescription

return.name: description
return.desc: The description string

functions.info:
All entities can have an associated description. For bodies and
shapes this can be provided through the editor. This function 
retrieves that description.
functions.example: local desc = GetDescription(body)

functions.name: SetDescription
functions.info:
All entities can have an associated description. The description for 
bodies and shapes will show up on the HUD when looking at them.
functions.example: SetDescription(body, "Target object")

functions.name: Delete
functions.info:
Remove an entity from the scene. All entities owned by this entity
will also be removed.
functions.example:
Delete(body)
--All shapes associated with body will also be removed

functions.name: IsHandleValid

return.name: exists
return.desc: Returns true if the entity pointed to by handle still exists

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
valid = IsHandleValid(body)

--valid is true if body still exists

Delete(body)
valid = IsHandleValid(body)

--valid will now be false

functions.name: GetEntityType

return.name: type
return.desc: Type name of the provided entity

functions.info: Returns the type name of provided entity, for example "body", "shape", "light", etc.
functions.example:
local t = GetEntityType(e)
if t == "body" then
	--e is a body handle
end

api.desc: A body represents a rigid body in the scene. It can be either static or dynamic. Only dynamic bodies are affected by physics.

functions.name: FindBody

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to first body with specified tag or zero if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Search for a body tagged "target" in script scope
local target = FindBody("target")

--Search for a body tagged "escape" in entire scene
local escape = FindBody("escape", true)

functions.name: FindBodies

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all bodies with specified tag

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Search for bodies tagged "target" in script scope
local targets = FindBodies("target")
for i=1, #targets do
	local target = targets[i]
	...
end

functions.name: GetBodyTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Transform of the body

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local t = GetBodyTransform(body)

functions.name: SetBodyTransform
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Move a body 1 meter upwards
local t = GetBodyTransform(body)
t.pos = VecAdd(t.pos, Vec(0, 1, 0))
SetBodyTransform(body, t)

functions.name: GetBodyMass

return.name: mass
return.desc: Body mass. Static bodies always return zero mass.

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local mass = GetBodyMass(body)

functions.name: IsBodyDynamic

return.name: dynamic
return.desc: Return true if body is dynamic

functions.info:
Check if body is dynamic. Note that something that was created static 
may become dynamic due to destruction.
functions.example: local dynamic = IsBodyDynamic(body)

functions.name: SetBodyDynamic

arguments.name: dynamic
arguments.desc: True for dynamic. False for static.

functions.info:
Change the dynamic state of a body. There is very limited use for this
function. In most situations you should leave it up to the engine to decide.
Use with caution.
functions.example: SetBodyDynamic(body, false)

functions.name: SetBodyVelocity

arguments.name: handle
arguments.desc: Body handle (should be a dynamic body)

functions.info:
This can be used for animating bodies with preserved physical interaction,
but in most cases you are better off with a motorized joint instead.
functions.example:
local vel = Vec(2,0,0)
SetBodyVelocity(body, vel)

functions.name: GetBodyVelocity

arguments.name: handle
arguments.desc: Body handle (should be a dynamic body)

return.name: velocity
return.desc: Linear velocity as vector

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local linVel = GetBodyVelocity(body)

functions.name: GetBodyVelocityAtPos

arguments.name: handle
arguments.desc: Body handle (should be a dynamic body)

return.name: velocity
return.desc: Linear velocity on body at pos as vector

functions.info: Return the velocity on a body taking both linear and angular velocity into account.
functions.example: local vel = GetBodyVelocityAtPos(body, pos)

functions.name: SetBodyAngularVelocity

arguments.name: handle
arguments.desc: Body handle (should be a dynamic body)

functions.info:
This can be used for animating bodies with preserved physical interaction,
but in most cases you are better off with a motorized joint instead.
functions.example:
local angVel = Vec(2,0,0)
SetBodyAngularVelocity(body, angVel)

functions.name: GetBodyAngularVelocity

arguments.name: handle
arguments.desc: Body handle (should be a dynamic body)

return.name: angVel
return.desc: Angular velocity as vector

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local angVel = GetBodyAngularVelocity(body)

functions.name: IsBodyActive

return.name: active
return.desc: Return true if body is active

functions.info:
Check if body is body is currently simulated. For performance reasons,
bodies that don't move are taken out of the simulation. This function
can be used to query the active state of a specific body. Only dynamic
bodies can be active.
functions.example:
if IsBodyActive(body) then
	...
end

functions.name: SetBodyActive

arguments.name: active
arguments.desc: Set to tru if body should be active (simulated)

functions.info:
This function makes it possible to manually activate and deactivate bodies to include or
exclude in simulation. The engine normally handles this automatically, so use with care.
functions.example:
--Wake up body
SetBodyActive(body, true)

--Put body to sleep
SetBodyActive(body, false)

functions.name: ApplyBodyImpulse

arguments.name: handle
arguments.desc: Body handle (should be a dynamic body)

functions.info: Apply impulse to dynamic body at position (give body a push).
functions.example:
local pos = Vec(0,1,0)
local imp = Vec(0,0,10)
ApplyBodyImpulse(body, pos, imp)

functions.name: GetBodyShapes

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table of shape handles

functions.info: Return handles to all shapes owned by a body
functions.example:
local shapes = GetBodyShapes(body)
for i=1,#shapes do
	local shape = shapes[i]
end

functions.name: GetBodyVehicle

return.name: handle
return.desc: Get parent vehicle for body, or zero if not part of vehicle

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local vehicle = GetBodyVehicle(body)

functions.name: GetBodyBounds

return.name: min
return.desc: Vector representing the AABB lower bound

return.name: max
return.desc: Vector representing the AABB upper bound

functions.info: Return the world space, axis-aligned bounding box for a body.
functions.example:
local min, max = GetBodyBounds(body)
local boundsSize = VecSub(max, min)
local center = VecLerp(min, max, 0.5)

functions.name: GetBodyCenterOfMass

return.name: point
return.desc: Vector representing local center of mass in body space

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Visualize center of mass on for body
local com = GetBodyCenterOfMass(body)
local worldPoint = TransformToParentPoint(GetBodyTransform(body), com)
DebugCross(worldPoint)

functions.name: IsBodyVisible

arguments.name: rejectTransparent
arguments.desc: See through transparent materials. Default false.

return.name: visible
return.desc: Return true if body is visible

functions.info:
This will check if a body is currently visible in the camera frustum and
not occluded by other objects.
functions.example:
if IsBodyVisible(body, 25) then
	--Body is within 25 meters visible to the camera
end

functions.name: IsBodyBroken

return.name: broken
return.desc: Return true if body is broken

functions.info: Determine if any shape of a body has been broken.
functions.example: local broken = IsBodyBroken(body)

functions.name: IsBodyJointedToStatic

return.name: result
return.desc: Return true if body is in any way connected to a static body

functions.info:
Determine if a body is in any way connected to a static object, either by being static itself or
be being directly or indirectly jointed to something static.
functions.example: local connectedToStatic = IsBodyJointedToStatic(body)

functions.name: DrawBodyOutline
functions.info:
Render next frame with an outline around specified body.
If no color is given, a white outline will be drawn.
functions.example:
--Draw white outline at 50% transparency
DrawBodyOutline(body, 0.5)

--Draw green outline, fully opaque
DrawBodyOutline(body, 0, 1, 0, 1)

functions.name: DrawBodyHighlight
functions.info:
Flash the appearance of a body when rendering this frame. This is
used for valuables in the game.
functions.example: DrawBodyHighlight(body, 0.5)

functions.name: GetBodyClosestPoint
functions.def: hit, point, normal, shape = GetBodyClosestPoint(body, origin)

return.name: hit
return.desc: True if a point was found

return.name: point
return.desc: World space closest point

return.name: normal
return.desc: World space normal at closest point

return.name: shape
return.desc: Handle to closest shape

functions.info: This will return the closest point of a specific body
functions.example:
local hit, p, n, s = GetBodyClosestPoint(body, Vec(0, 5, 0))
if hit then
	--Point p of shape s is closest
end

functions.name: ConstrainVelocity

arguments.name: relVel
arguments.desc: Desired relative velocity along the provided direction

functions.info:
This will tell the physics solver to constrain the velocity between two bodies. The physics solver
will try to reach the desired goal, while not applying an impulse bigger than the min and max values.
This function should only be used from the update callback.
functions.example:
--Constrain the velocity between bodies A and B so that the relative velocity 
--along the X axis at point (0, 5, 0) is always 3 m/s
ConstrainVelocity(a, b, Vec(0, 5, 0), Vec(1, 0, 0), 3)

functions.name: ConstrainAngularVelocity

arguments.name: relAngVel
arguments.desc: Desired relative angular velocity along the provided direction

functions.info:
This will tell the physics solver to constrain the angular velocity between two bodies. The physics solver
will try to reach the desired goal, while not applying an angular impulse bigger than the min and max values.
This function should only be used from the update callback.
functions.example:
--Constrain the angular velocity between bodies A and B so that the relative angular velocity
--along the Y axis is always 3 rad/s
ConstrainAngularVelocity(a, b, Vec(1, 0, 0), 3)

functions.name: ConstrainPosition

arguments.name: pointA
arguments.desc: World space point for first body

arguments.name: pointB
arguments.desc: World space point for second body

functions.info:
This is a helper function that uses ConstrainVelocity to constrain a point on one 
body to a point on another body while not affecting the bodies more than the provided 
maximum relative velocity and maximum impulse. In other words: physically push on
the bodies so that pointA and pointB are aligned in world space. This is useful for 
physically animating objects. This function should only be used from the update callback.
functions.example:
--Constrain the origo of body a to an animated point in the world
local worldPos = Vec(0, 3+math.sin(GetTime()), 0)
ConstrainPosition(a, 0, GetBodyTransform(a).pos, worldPos)

--Constrain the origo of body a to the origo of body b (like a ball joint)
ConstrainPosition(a, b, GetBodyTransform(a).pos, GetBodyTransform(b).pos)

functions.name: ConstrainOrientation

arguments.name: quatA
arguments.desc: World space orientation for first body

arguments.name: quatB
arguments.desc: World space orientation for second body

functions.info:
This is the angular counterpart to ConstrainPosition, a helper function that uses
ConstrainAngularVelocity to constrain the orientation of one body to the orientation
on another body while not affecting the bodies more than the provided maximum relative
angular velocity and maximum angular impulse. In other words: physically rotate the
bodies so that quatA and quatB are aligned in world space. This is useful for 
physically animating objects. This function should only be used from the update callback.
functions.example:
--Constrain the orietation of body a to an upright orientation in the world
ConstrainOrientation(a, 0, GetBodyTransform(a).rot, Quat())

--Constrain the orientation of body a to the orientation of body b
ConstrainOrientation(a, b, GetBodyTransform(a).rot, GetBodyTransform(b).rot)

functions.name: GetWorldBody

return.name: body
return.desc: Handle to the static world body

functions.info: Every scene in Teardown has an implicit static world body that contains all shapes that are not explicitly assigned a body in the editor.
functions.example: local w = GetWorldBody()

api.desc: A shape is a voxel object and always owned by a body. A single body may contain multiple shapes. The transform of shape is expressed in the parent body coordinate system.

functions.name: FindShape

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to first shape with specified tag or zero if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Search for a shape tagged "mybox" in script scope
local target = FindShape("mybox")

--Search for a shape tagged "laserturret" in entire scene
local escape = FindShape("laserturret", true)

functions.name: FindShapes

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all shapes with specified tag

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Search for shapes tagged "alarmbox" in script scope
local shapes = FindShapes("alarmbox")
for i=1, #shapes do
	local shape = shapes[i]
	...
end

functions.name: GetShapeLocalTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Return shape transform in body space

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Shape transform in body local space
local shapeTransform = GetShapeLocalTransform(shape)

--Body transform in world space
local bodyTransform = GetBodyTransform(GetShapeBody(shape))

--Shape transform in world space
local worldTranform = TransformToParentTransform(bodyTransform, shapeTransform)

functions.name: SetShapeLocalTransform
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local transform = Transform(Vec(0, 1, 0), QuatEuler(0, 90, 0))
SetShapeLocalTransform(shape, transform)

functions.name: GetShapeWorldTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Return shape transform in world space

functions.info: This is a convenience function, transforming the shape out of body space
functions.example:
local worldTransform = GetShapeWorldTransform(shape)

--This is equivalent to
local shapeTransform = GetShapeLocalTransform(shape)
local bodyTransform = GetBodyTransform(GetShapeBody(shape))
worldTranform = TransformToParentTransform(bodyTransform, shapeTransform)

functions.name: GetShapeBody

return.name: handle
return.desc: Body handle

functions.info:
Get handle to the body this shape is owned by. A shape is always owned by a body,
but can be transfered to a new body during destruction.
functions.example: local body = GetShapeBody(shape)

functions.name: GetShapeJoints

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with joints connected to shape

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local hinges = GetShapeJoints(door)
for i=1, #hinges do
	local joint = hinges[i]
	...
end

functions.name: GetShapeLights

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table of lights owned by shape

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local lights = GetShapeLights(shape)
for i=1, #lights do
	local light = lights[i]
	...
end

functions.name: GetShapeBounds

return.name: min
return.desc: Vector representing the AABB lower bound

return.name: max
return.desc: Vector representing the AABB upper bound

functions.info: Return the world space, axis-aligned bounding box for a shape.
functions.example:
local min, max = GetShapeBounds(shape)
local boundsSize = VecSub(max, min)
local center = VecLerp(min, max, 0.5)

functions.name: SetShapeEmissiveScale
functions.info:
Scale emissiveness for shape. If the shape has light sources attached,
their intensity will be scaled by the same amount.
functions.example:
--Pulsate emissiveness and light intensity for shape
local scale = math.sin(GetTime())*0.5 + 0.5
SetShapeEmissiveScale(shape, scale)

functions.name: GetShapeMaterialAtPosition
functions.def: type, r, g, b, a = GetShapeMaterialAtPosition(handle, pos)

return.name: type
return.desc: Material type

return.name: r
return.desc: Red

return.name: g
return.desc: Green

return.name: b
return.desc: Blue

return.name: a
return.desc: Alpha

functions.info: Return material properties for a particular voxel
functions.example:
local hit, dist, normal, shape = QueryRaycast(pos, dir, 10)
if hit then
	local hitPoint = VecAdd(pos, VecScale(dir, dist))
	local mat = GetShapeMaterialAtPosition(shape, hitPoint)
	DebugPrint("Raycast hit voxel made out of " .. mat)
end

functions.name: GetShapeMaterialAtIndex
functions.def: type, r, g, b, a = GetShapeMaterialAtIndex(handle, x, y, z)

return.name: type
return.desc: Material type

return.name: r
return.desc: Red

return.name: g
return.desc: Green

return.name: b
return.desc: Blue

return.name: a
return.desc: Alpha

functions.info:
Return material properties for a particular voxel in the voxel grid indexed by integer values.
The first index is zero (not one, as opposed to a lot of lua related things)
functions.example:
local mat = GetShapeMaterialAtIndex(shape, 0, 0, 0)
DebugPrint("The voxel closest to origo is of material: " .. mat)

functions.name: GetShapeSize

return.name: xsize
return.desc: Size in voxels along x axis

return.name: ysize
return.desc: Size in voxels along y axis

return.name: zsize
return.desc: Size in voxels along z axis

return.name: scale
return.desc: The size of one voxel in meters (with default scale it is 0.1)

functions.info: Return the size of a shape in voxels
functions.example: local x, y, z = GetShapeSize(shape)

functions.name: GetShapeVoxelCount

return.name: count
return.desc: Number of voxels in shape

functions.info: Return the number of voxels in a shape, not including empty space
functions.example: local voxelCount = GetShapeVoxelCount(shape)

functions.name: IsShapeVisible

arguments.name: rejectTransparent
arguments.desc: See through transparent materials. Default false.

return.name: visible
return.desc: Return true if shape is visible

functions.info:
This will check if a shape is currently visible in the camera frustum and
not occluded by other objects.
functions.example:
if IsShapeVisible(shape, 25) then
	--Shape is within 25 meters visible to the camera
end

functions.name: IsShapeBroken

return.name: broken
return.desc: Return true if shape is broken

functions.info:
Determine if shape has been broken. Note that a shape can be transfered
to another body during destruction, but might still not be considered
broken if all voxels are intact.
functions.example: local broken = IsShapeBroken(shape)

functions.name: DrawShapeOutline
functions.info:
Render next frame with an outline around specified shape.
If no color is given, a white outline will be drawn.
functions.example:
--Draw white outline at 50% transparency
DrawShapeOutline(shape, 0.5)

--Draw green outline, fully opaque
DrawShapeOutline(shape, 0, 1, 0, 1)

functions.name: DrawShapeHighlight
functions.info: Flash the appearance of a shape when rendering this frame.
functions.example: DrawShapeHighlight(shape, 0.5)

functions.name: SetShapeCollisionFilter
functions.info:
This is used to filter out collisions with other shapes. Each shape can be given a layer 
bitmask (8 bits, 0-255) along with a mask (also 8 bits). The layer of one object must be in
the mask of the other object and vice versa for the collision to be valid. The default layer
for all objects is 1 and the default mask is 255 (collide with all layers).
functions.example:
--This will put shapes a and b in layer 2 and disable collisions with
--object shapes in layers 2, preventing any collisions between the two.
SetShapeCollisionFilter(a, 2, 255-2)
SetShapeCollisionFilter(b, 2, 255-2)

--This will put shapes c and d in layer 4 and allow collisions with other
--shapes in layer 4, but ignore all other collisions with the rest of the world.
SetShapeCollisionFilter(c, 4, 4)
SetShapeCollisionFilter(d, 4, 4)

functions.name: GetShapeClosestPoint

return.name: hit
return.desc: True if a point was found

return.name: point
return.desc: World space closest point

return.name: normal
return.desc: World space normal at closest point

functions.info: This will return the closest point of a specific shape
functions.example:
local hit, p, n = GetShapeClosestPoint(s, Vec(0, 5, 0))
if hit then
	--Point p of shape s is closest to (0,5,0)
end

functions.name: IsShapeTouching

return.name: touching
return.desc: True is shapes a and b are touching each other

functions.info: This will check if two shapes has physical overlap
functions.example:
local touch = IsShapeTouching(a, b)
if hit then
	--Shapes are touching or overlapping
end

api.desc: Locations are transforms placed in the editor as markers. Location transforms are always expressed in world space coordinates.

return.name: handle

functions.example: local loc = FindLocation("start")

functions.name: FindLocations

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all locations with specified tag

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Search for locations tagged "waypoint" in script scope
local locations = FindLocations("waypoint")
for i=1, #locs do
	local locs = locations[i]
	...
end

functions.name: GetLocationTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Transform of the location

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local t = GetLocationTransform(loc)

api.desc: Joints are used to physically connect two shapes. There are several types of joints and they are typically placed in the editor. When destruction occurs, joints may be transferred to new shapes, detached or completely disabled.

functions.name: FindJoint

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to first joint with specified tag or zero if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local joint = FindJoint("doorhinge")

functions.name: FindJoints

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all joints with specified tag

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Search for locations tagged "doorhinge" in script scope
local hinges = FindJoints("doorhinge")
for i=1, #hinges do
	local joint = hinges[i]
	...
end

functions.name: IsJointBroken

return.name: broken
return.desc: True if joint is broken

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local broken = IsJointBroken(joint)

functions.name: GetJointType

return.name: type
return.desc: Joint type

functions.info:
Joint type is one of the following: "ball", "hinge", "prismatic" or "rope".
An empty string is returned if joint handle is invalid.
functions.example:
if GetJointType(joint) == "rope" then
	--Joint is rope
end

functions.name: GetJointOtherShape

return.name: other
return.desc: Other shape handle

functions.info:
A joint is always connected to two shapes. Use this function if you know 
one shape and want to find the other one.
functions.example:
--joint is connected to a and b

otherShape = GetJointOtherShape(joint, a)
--otherShape is now b

otherShape = GetJointOtherShape(joint, b)
--otherShape is now a

functions.name: GetJointShapes

return.name: shapes
return.desc: Shape handles

functions.info: Get shapes connected to the joint.
functions.example:
-- Check to see if joint chain is still connected to vehicle main body
-- If not then disable motors

local mainBody = GetVehicleBody(vehicle)
local shapes = GetJointShapes(joint)

local connected = false
for i=1,#shapes do

	local body = GetShapeBody(shapes[i])

	if body == mainBody then
		connected = true
	end

end

if connected then
	SetJointMotor(joint, 0.5)
else
	SetJointMotor(joint, 0.0)
end

functions.name: SetJointMotor

arguments.name: strength
arguments.desc: Desired strength. Default is infinite. Zero to disable.

functions.info:
Set joint motor target velocity. If joint is of type hinge, velocity is
given in radians per second angular velocity. If joint type is prismatic joint
velocity is given in meters per second. Calling this function will override and
void any previous call to SetJointMotorTarget.
functions.example:
--Set motor speed to 0.5 radians per second
SetJointMotor(hinge, 0.5)

functions.name: SetJointMotorTarget

arguments.name: maxVel
arguments.desc: Maximum velocity to reach target. Default is infinite.

arguments.name: strength
arguments.desc: Desired strength. Default is infinite. Zero to disable.

functions.info:
If a joint has a motor target, it will try to maintain its relative movement. This
is very useful for elevators or other animated, jointed mechanisms.
If joint is of type hinge, target is an angle in degrees (-180 to 180) and velocity
is given in radians per second. If joint type is prismatic, target is given
in meters and velocity is given in meters per second. Setting a motor target will
override any previous call to SetJointMotor.
functions.example:
--Make joint reach a 45 degree angle, going at a maximum of 3 radians per second
SetJointMotorTarget(hinge, 45, 3)

functions.name: GetJointLimits

return.name: min
return.desc: Minimum joint limit (angle or distance)

return.name: max
return.desc: Maximum joint limit (angle or distance)

functions.info:
Return joint limits for hinge or prismatic joint. Returns angle or distance
depending on joint type.
functions.example: local min, max = GetJointLimits(hinge)

functions.name: GetJointMovement

return.name: movement
return.desc: Current joint position or angle

functions.info:
Return the current position or angle or the joint, measured in same way
as joint limits.
functions.example: local current = GetJointMovement(hinge)

functions.name: GetJointedBodies

return.name: bodies
return.desc: Handles to all dynamic bodies in the jointed structure. The input handle will also be included.

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Draw outline for all bodies in jointed structure
local all = GetJointedBodies(body)
for i=1,#all do
	DrawBodyOutline(all[i], 0.5)
end

functions.name: DetachJointFromShape
functions.info: Detach joint from shape. If joint is not connected to shape, nothing happens.
functions.example: DetachJointFromShape(hinge, door)

api.desc: Light sources can be of several differnt types and configured in the editor. If a light source is owned by a shape, the intensity of the light source is scaled by the emissive scale of that shape. If the parent shape breaks, the emissive scale is set to zero and the light source is disabled. A light source without a parent shape will always emit light, unless exlicitly disabled by a script.

functions.name: FindLight

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to first light with specified tag or zero if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local light = FindLight("main")

functions.name: FindLights

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all lights with specified tag

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Search for lights tagged "main" in script scope
local lights = FindLights("main")
for i=1, #lights do
	local light = lights[i]
	...
end

functions.name: SetLightEnabled

arguments.name: enabled
arguments.desc: Set to true if light should be enabled

functions.info:
If light is owned by a shape, the emissive scale of that shape will be set
to 0.0 when light is disabled and 1.0 when light is enabled.
functions.example: SetLightEnabled(light, false)

functions.name: SetLightColor
functions.info:
This will only set the color tint of the light. Use SetLightIntensity for brightness.
Setting the light color will not affect the emissive color of a parent shape.
functions.example:
--Set light color to yellow
SetLightColor(light, 1, 1, 0)

functions.name: SetLightIntensity
functions.info:
If the shape is owned by a shape you most likely want to use
SetShapeEmissiveScale instead, which will affect both the emissiveness 
of the shape and the brightness of the light at the same time.
functions.example:
--Pulsate light
SetLightIntensity(light, math.sin(GetTime())*0.5 + 1.0)

functions.name: GetLightTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: World space light transform

functions.info: Lights that are owned by a dynamic shape are automatcially moved with that shape
functions.example: local pos = GetLightTransform(light).pos

functions.name: GetLightShape

return.name: handle
return.desc: Shape handle or zero if not attached to shape

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local shape = GetLightShape(light)

functions.name: IsLightActive

return.name: active
return.desc: True if light is currently emitting light

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if IsLightActive(light) then
	--Do something
end

functions.name: IsPointAffectedByLight

return.name: affected
return.desc: Return true if point is in light cone and range

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local point = Vec(0, 10, 0)
local affected = IsPointAffectedByLight(light, point)

api.desc: Triggers can be placed in the scene and queried by scripts to see if something is within a certain part of the scene.

functions.name: FindTrigger

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to first trigger with specified tag or zero if not found

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local goal = FindTrigger("goal")

functions.name: FindTriggers

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all triggers with specified tag

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Find triggers tagged "toxic" in script scope
local triggers = FindTriggers("toxic")
for i=1, #triggers do
	local trigger = triggers[i]
	...
end

functions.name: GetTriggerTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Current trigger transform in world space

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local t = GetTriggerTransform(trigger)

functions.name: SetTriggerTransform

arguments.name: transform
arguments.desc: Desired trigger transform in world space

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local t = Transform(Vec(0, 1, 0), QuatEuler(0, 90, 0))
SetTriggerTransform(trigger, t)

functions.name: GetTriggerBounds

return.name: min
return.desc: Lower point of trigger bounds in world space

return.name: max
return.desc: Upper point of trigger bounds in world space

functions.info: Return the lower and upper points in world space of the trigger axis aligned bounding box
functions.example:
local mi, ma = GetTriggerBounds(trigger)
local list = QueryAabbShapes(mi, ma)

functions.name: IsBodyInTrigger

return.name: inside
return.desc: True if body is in trigger volume

functions.info: This function will only check the center point of the body
functions.example:
if IsBodyInTrigger(trigger, body) then
	...
end

functions.name: IsVehicleInTrigger

return.name: inside
return.desc: True if vehicle is in trigger volume

functions.info: This function will only check origo of vehicle
functions.example:
if IsVehicleInTrigger(trigger, vehicle) then
	...

functions.name: IsShapeInTrigger

return.name: inside
return.desc: True if shape is in trigger volume

functions.info: This function will only check the center point of the shape
functions.example:
if IsShapeInTrigger(trigger, shape) then
	...
end

functions.name: IsPointInTrigger

return.name: inside
return.desc: True if point is in trigger volume

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local p = Vec(0, 10, 0)
if IsPointInTrigger(trigger, p) then
	...
end

functions.name: IsTriggerEmpty

arguments.name: demolision
arguments.desc: If true, small debris and vehicles are ignored

return.name: empty
return.desc: True if trigger is empty

return.name: maxpoint
return.desc: World space point of highest point (largest Y coordinate) if not empty

functions.info:
This function will check if trigger is empty. If trigger contains any part of a body
it will return false and the highest point as second return value.
functions.example:
local empty, highPoint = IsTriggerEmpty(trigger)
if not empty then
	--highPoint[2] is the tallest point in trigger
end

functions.name: GetTriggerDistance

return.name: distance
return.desc: Positive if point is outside, negative if inside

functions.info: Get distance to the surface of trigger volume. Will return negative distance if inside.
functions.example:
local p = Vec(0, 10, 0)
local dist = GetTriggerDistance(trigger, p)

functions.name: GetTriggerClosestPoint

return.name: closest
return.desc: Closest point in trigger as vector

functions.info:
Return closest point in trigger volume. Will return the input point itself if inside trigger
or closest point on surface of trigger if outside.
functions.example:
local p = Vec(0, 10, 0)
local closest = GetTriggerClosestPoint(trigger, p)
