return.name: body
return.desc: Main body of vehicle

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local body = GetVehicleBody(vehicle)
if IsBodyBroken(body) then
--Vehicle body is broken
end

functions.name: GetVehicleHealth

return.name: health
return.desc: Vehicle health (zero to one)

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local health = GetVehicleHealth(vehicle)

functions.name: GetVehicleDriverPos

return.name: pos
return.desc: Driver position as vector in vehicle space

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local driverPos = GetVehicleDriverPos(vehicle)
local t = GetVehicleTransform(vehicle)
local worldPos = TransformToParentPoint(t, driverPos)

functions.name: DriveVehicle
functions.info:
This function applies input to vehicles, allowing for autonomous driving. The vehicle
will be turned on automatically and turned off when no longer called. Call this from
the tick function, not update.
functions.example:
function tick()
	--Drive mycar forwards
	local v = FindVehicle("mycar")
	DriveVehicle(v, 1, 0, false)
end

api.desc: The player functions expose certain information about the player.

functions.name: GetPlayerPos

return.name: position
return.desc: Player center position

functions.info:
Return center point of player. This function is deprecated. 
Use GetPlayerTransform instead.
functions.example:
local p = GetPlayerPos()

--This is equivalent to
p = VecAdd(GetPlayerTransform().pos, Vec(0,1,0))

functions.name: GetPlayerTransform

arguments.name: includePitch
arguments.desc: Include the player pitch (look up/down) in transform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Current player transform

functions.info:
The player transform is located at the bottom of the player. The player transform
considers heading (looking left and right). Forward is along negative Z axis.
Player pitch (looking up and down) does not affect player transform unless includePitch
is set to true. If you want the transform of the eye, use GetPlayerCameraTransform() instead.
functions.example: local t = GetPlayerTransform()

functions.name: SetPlayerTransform

arguments.name: includePitch
arguments.desc: Set player pitch (look up/down) as well

functions.info:
Instantly teleport the player to desired transform. Unless includePitch is
set to true, up/down look angle will be set to zero during this process.
Player velocity will be reset to zero.
functions.example:
local t = Transform(Vec(10, 0, 0), QuatEuler(0, 90, 0))
SetPlayerTransform(t)

functions.name: SetPlayerGroundVelocity
functions.info: Make the ground act as a conveyor belt, pushing the player even if ground shape is static.
functions.example: SetPlayerGroundVelocity(Vec(2,0,0))

functions.name: GetPlayerCameraTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Current player camera transform

functions.info:
The player camera transform is usually the same as what you get from GetCameraTransform,
but if you have set a camera transform manually with SetCameraTransform, you can retrieve
the standard player camera transform with this function.
functions.example: local t = GetPlayerCameraTransform()

functions.name: SetPlayerCameraOffsetTransform
functions.info:
Call this function continously to apply a camera offset. Can be used for camera effects 
such as shake and wobble.
functions.example:
local t = Transform(Vec(), QuatAxisAngle(Vec(1, 0, 0), math.sin(time*3.0) * 3.0))
SetPlayerCameraOffsetTransform(t)

functions.name: SetPlayerSpawnTransform
functions.info: Call this function during init to alter the player spawn transform.
functions.example:
local t = Transform(Vec(10, 0, 0), QuatEuler(0, 90, 0))
SetPlayerSpawnTransform(t)

functions.name: GetPlayerVelocity

return.name: velocity
return.desc: Player velocity in world space as vector

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local vel = GetPlayerVelocity()

functions.name: SetPlayerVehicle

arguments.name: vehicle
arguments.desc: Handle to vehicle or zero to not drive.

functions.info: Drive specified vehicle.
functions.example:
local car = FindVehicle("mycar")
SetPlayerVehicle(car)

functions.name: SetPlayerVelocity

arguments.name: velocity
arguments.desc: Player velocity in world space as vector

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: SetPlayerVelocity(Vec(0, 5, 0))

functions.name: GetPlayerVehicle

return.name: handle
return.desc: Current vehicle handle, or zero if not in vehicle

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local vehicle = GetPlayerVehicle()
if vehicle ~= 0 then
	...
end

functions.name: GetPlayerGrabShape

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to grabbed shape or zero if not grabbing.

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local shape = GetPlayerGrabShape()
if shape ~= 0 then
	...
end

functions.name: GetPlayerGrabBody

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to grabbed body or zero if not grabbing.

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local body = GetPlayerGrabBody()
if body ~= 0 then
	...
end

functions.name: ReleasePlayerGrab
functions.info: Release what the player is currently holding
functions.example: ReleasePlayerGrab()

functions.name: GetPlayerPickShape

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to picked shape or zero if nothing is picked

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local shape = GetPlayerPickShape()
if shape ~= 0 then
	...
end

functions.name: GetPlayerPickBody

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to picked body or zero if nothing is picked

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local body = GetPlayerPickBody()
if body ~= 0 then
	...
end

functions.name: GetPlayerInteractShape

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to interactable shape or zero

functions.info:
Interactable shapes has to be tagged with "interact". The engine
determines which interactable shape is currently interactable.
functions.example:
local shape = GetPlayerInteractShape()
if shape ~= 0 then
	...
end

functions.name: GetPlayerInteractBody

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to interactable body or zero

functions.info:
Interactable shapes has to be tagged with "interact". The engine
determines which interactable body is currently interactable.
functions.example:
local body = GetPlayerInteractBody()
if body ~= 0 then
	...
end

functions.name: SetPlayerScreen

arguments.name: handle
arguments.desc: Handle to screen or zero for no screen

functions.info:
Set the screen the player should interact with. For the screen
to feature a mouse pointer and receieve input, the screen also
needs to have interactive property.
functions.example:
--Interact with screen
SetPlayerScreen(screen)

--Do not interact with screen
SetPlayerScreen(0)

functions.name: GetPlayerScreen

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to interacted screen or zero if none

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Interact with screen
local screen = GetPlayerScreen()

functions.name: SetPlayerHealth

arguments.name: health
arguments.desc: Set player health (between zero and one)

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: SetPlayerHealth(0.5)

functions.name: GetPlayerHealth

return.name: health
return.desc: Current player health

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local health = GetPlayerHealth()

functions.name: RespawnPlayer
functions.info: Respawn player at spawn position without modifying the scene
functions.example: RespawnPlayer()

functions.name: RegisterTool

arguments.name: name
arguments.desc: Tool name to show in hud

arguments.name: group
arguments.desc: Tool group for this tool (1-6) Default is 6.

functions.info:
Register a custom tool that will show up in the player inventory and 
can be selected with scroll wheel. Do this only once per tool.
You also need to enable the tool in the registry before it can be used.
functions.example:
function init()
	RegisterTool("lasergun", "Laser Gun", "MOD/vox/lasergun.vox")
	SetBool("game.tool.lasergun.enabled", true)
end

function tick()
	if GetString("game.player.tool") == "lasergun" then
		--Tool is selected. Tool logic goes here.
	end
end

functions.name: GetToolBody

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to currently visible tool body or zero if none

functions.info:
Return body handle of the visible tool. You can use this to retrieve tool shapes
and animate them, change emissiveness, etc. Do not attempt to set the tool body
transform, since it is controlled by the engine. Use SetToolTranform for that.
functions.example:
local toolBody = GetToolBody()
if toolBody~=0 then
	...
end

functions.name: SetToolTransform
functions.info:
Apply an additional transform on the visible tool body. This can be used to
create tool animations. You need to set this every frame from the tick function.
The optional sway parameter control the amount of tool swaying when walking.
Set to zero to disable completely.
functions.example:
--Offset the tool half a meter to the right
local offset = Transform(Vec(0.5, 0, 0))
SetToolTransform(offset)

api.desc: Sound functions are used for playing sounds or loops in the world. There sound functions are alwyas positioned and will be affected by acoustics simulation. If you want to play dry sounds without acoustics you should use UiSound and UiSoundLoop in the User Interface section.

functions.name: LoadSound

arguments.name: nominalDistance
arguments.desc: The distance in meters this sound is recorded at. Affects attenuation, default is 10.0

return.name: handle
return.desc: Sound handle

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local snd = LoadSound("beep.ogg")

functions.name: LoadLoop

arguments.name: nominalDistance
arguments.desc: The distance in meters this sound is recorded at. Affects attenuation, default is 10.0

return.name: handle
return.desc: Loop handle

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local loop = LoadLoop("siren.ogg")

functions.name: PlaySound

arguments.name: pos
arguments.desc: World position as vector. Default is player position.

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
function init()
	snd = LoadSound("beep.ogg")
end

function tick()
	if trigSound then
		local pos = Vec(100, 0, 0)
		PlaySound(snd, pos, 0.5)
	end
end

If you have a list of sound files and you add a sequence number, starting from zero, at the end of each filename like below,
then each time you call PlaySound it will pick a random sound from that list and play that sound.

"example-sound0.ogg"
"example-sound1.ogg"
"example-sound2.ogg"
"example-sound3.ogg"
...

function init()
	--Load sound serie, OBS no ".ogg" or sequence number in filename
	snd = LoadSound("example-sound")
end

Plays a random sound from the loaded sound series
function tick()
	if trigSound then
		local pos = Vec(100, 0, 0)
		PlaySound(snd, pos, 0.5)
	end
end

functions.name: PlayLoop

arguments.name: pos
arguments.desc: World position as vector. Default is player position.

functions.info: Call this function continuously to play loop
functions.example:
function init()
	loop = LoadLoop("siren.ogg")
end

function tick()
	local pos = Vec(100, 0, 0)
	PlayLoop(loop, pos, 0.5)
end

functions.name: PlayMusic
functions.info: No Description
functions.example: PlayMusic("MOD/music/background.ogg")

functions.name: StopMusic
functions.info: No Description
functions.example: StopMusic()

api.desc: Sprites are 2D images in PNG or JPG format that can be drawn into the world. Sprites can be drawn with ot without depth test (occluded by geometry). Sprites will not be affected by lighting but they will go through post processing. If you want to display positioned information to the player as an overlay, you probably want to use the Ui functions in combination with UiWorldToPixel instead.

functions.name: LoadSprite

arguments.name: path
arguments.desc: Path to sprite. Must be PNG or JPG format.

return.name: handle
return.desc: Sprite handle

functions.info: No Description

functions.name: DrawSprite
functions.info: Draw sprite in world at next frame. Call this function from the tick callback.
functions.example:
function init()
	arrow = LoadSprite("arrow.png")
end

function tick()
	--Draw sprite using transform
	--Size is two meters in width and height
	--Color is white, fully opaue
	local t = Transform(Vec(0, 10, 0), QuatEuler(0, GetTime(), 0))
	DrawSprite(arrow, t, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1)
end

api.desc: Query the level in various ways.

functions.name: QueryRequire
functions.info:
Set required layers for next query. Available layers are:

Layer  Description
physical	 have a physical representationdynamic		 part of a dynamic bodystatic		 part of a static bodylarge		 above debris thresholdsmall		 below debris threshold
functions.example:
--Raycast dynamic, physical objects above debris threshold, but not specific vehicle
QueryRequire("physical dynamic large")
QueryRejectVehicle(vehicle)
QueryRaycast(...)

functions.name: QueryRejectVehicle
functions.info: Exclude vehicle from the next query
functions.example:
--Do not include vehicle in next raycast
QueryRejectVehicle(vehicle)
QueryRaycast(...)

functions.name: QueryRejectBody
functions.info: Exclude body from the next query
functions.example:
--Do not include body in next raycast
QueryRejectBody(body)
QueryRaycast(...)

functions.name: QueryRejectShape
functions.info: Exclude shape from the next query
functions.example:
--Do not include shape in next raycast
QueryRejectShape(shape)
QueryRaycast(...)

functions.name: QueryRaycast
functions.def: hit, dist, normal, shape = QueryRaycast(origin, direction, maxDist, [radius], [rejectTransparent])

arguments.name: origin
arguments.desc: Raycast origin as world space vector

arguments.name: direction
arguments.desc: Unit length raycast direction as world space vector

arguments.name: maxDist
arguments.desc: Raycast maximum distance. Keep this as low as possible for good performance.

arguments.name: rejectTransparent
arguments.desc: Raycast through transparent materials. Default false.

return.name: hit
return.desc: True if raycast hit something

return.name: dist
return.desc: Hit distance from origin

return.name: normal
return.desc: World space normal at hit point

return.name: shape
return.desc: Handle to hit shape

functions.info:
This will perform a raycast or spherecast (if radius is more than zero) query.
If you want to set up a filter for the query you need to do so before every call
to this function.
functions.example:
--Raycast from a high point straight downwards, excluding a specific vehicle
QueryRejectVehicle(vehicle)
local hit, d = QueryRaycast(Vec(0, 100, 0), Vec(0, -1, 0), 100)
if hit then
	...hit something at distance d
end

functions.name: QueryClosestPoint
functions.def: hit, point, normal, shape = QueryClosestPoint(origin, maxDist)

arguments.name: maxDist
arguments.desc: Maximum distance. Keep this as low as possible for good performance.

return.name: hit
return.desc: True if a point was found

return.name: point
return.desc: World space closest point

return.name: normal
return.desc: World space normal at closest point

return.name: shape
return.desc: Handle to closest shape

functions.info:
This will query the closest point to all shapes in the world. If you 
want to set up a filter for the query you need to do so before every call
to this function.
functions.example:
--Find closest point within 10 meters of {0, 5, 0}, excluding any point on myVehicle
QueryRejectVehicle(myVehicle)
local hit, p, n, s = QueryClosestPoint(Vec(0, 5, 0), 10)
if hit then
	--Point p of shape s is closest
end

functions.name: QueryAabbShapes

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all shapes in the aabb

functions.info: Return all shapes within the provided world space, axis-aligned bounding box
functions.example:
local list = QueryAabbShapes(Vec(0, 0, 0), Vec(10, 10, 10))
for i=1, #list do
	local shape = list[i]
	..
end

functions.name: QueryAabbBodies

return.name: list
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all bodies in the aabb

functions.info: Return all bodies within the provided world space, axis-aligned bounding box
functions.example:
local list = QueryAabbBodies(Vec(0, 0, 0), Vec(10, 10, 10))
for i=1, #list do
	local body = list[i]
	..
end

functions.name: QueryPath

arguments.name: maxDist
arguments.desc: Maximum path length before giving up. Default is infinite.

arguments.name: targetRadius
arguments.desc: Maximum allowed distance to target in meters. Default is 2.0

functions.info:
Initiate path planning query. The result will run asynchronously as long as GetPathState
retuns "busy". An ongoing path query can be aborted with AbortPath. The path planning query
will use the currently set up query filter, just like the other query functions.
functions.example: QueryPath(Vec(-10, 0, 0), Vec(10, 0, 0))

functions.name: AbortPath
functions.info:
Abort current path query, regardless of what state it is currently in. This is a way to
save computing resources if the result of the current query is no longer of interest.
functions.example: AbortPath()

functions.name: GetPathState

return.name: state
return.desc: Current path planning state

functions.info:
Return the current state of the last path planning query.

State  Description
idle	 No recent querybusy	 Busy computing. No path found yet.fail	 Failed to find path. You can still get the resulting path (even though it won't reach the target).done	 Path planning completed and a path was found. Get it with GetPathLength and GetPathPoint)
functions.example:
local s = GetPathState()
if s == "done" then
	DoSomething()
end

functions.name: GetPathLength

return.name: length
return.desc: Length of last path planning result (in meters)

functions.info:
Return the path length of the most recently computed path query. Note that the result can often be retrieved even
if the path query failed. If the target point couldn't be reached, the path endpoint will be the point closest
to the target.
functions.example: local l = GetPathLength()

functions.name: GetPathPoint

arguments.name: dist
arguments.desc: The distance along path. Should be between zero and result from GetPathLength()

return.name: point
return.desc: The path point dist meters along the path

functions.info:
Return a point along the path for the most recently computed path query. Note that the result can often be retrieved even
if the path query failed. If the target point couldn't be reached, the path endpoint will be the point closest
to the target.
functions.example:
local d = 0
local l = GetPathLength()
while d < l do
	DebugCross(GetPathPoint(d))
	d = d + 0.5
end

functions.name: GetLastSound

return.name: volume
return.desc: Volume of loudest sound played last frame

return.name: position
return.desc: World position of loudest sound played last frame

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local vol, pos = GetLastSound()

functions.name: IsPointInWater

return.name: inWater
return.desc: True if point is in water

return.name: depth
return.desc: Depth of point into water, or zero if not in water

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local wet, d = IsPointInWater(Vec(10, 0, 0))
if wet then
	...point d meters into water
end

functions.name: GetWindVelocity

return.name: vel
return.desc: Wind at provided position

functions.info:
Get the wind velocity at provided point. The wind will be determined by wind property of
the environment, but it varies with position procedurally.
functions.example: local v = GetWindVelocity(Vec(0, 10, 0))

api.desc:
Functions to configure and emit particles, used for fire, smoke and other visual effects. There are two types of particles in Teardown - plain particles and smoke particles. Plain particles are simple billboard particles simulated with gravity and velocity that can be used for fire, debris, rain, snow and such. Smoke particles are only intended for smoke and they are simulated with fluid dynamics internally and rendered with some special tricks to get a more smoke-like appearance.
All functions in the particle API, except for SpawnParticle modify properties in the particle state, which is then used when emitting particles, so the idea is to set up a state, and then emit one or several particles using that state.
Most properties in the particle state can be either constant or animated over time. Supply a single argument for constant, two argument for linear interpolation, and optionally a third argument for other types of interpolation. There are also fade in and fade out parameters that fade from and to zero.

functions.name: ParticleReset
functions.info:
Reset to default particle state, which is a plain, white particle of radius 0.5.
Collision is enabled and it alpha animates from 1 to 0.
functions.example: ParticleReset()

functions.name: ParticleType

arguments.name: type
arguments.desc: Type of particle. Can be "smoke" or "plain".

functions.info: Set type of particle
functions.example: ParticleType("smoke")

functions.name: ParticleTile

arguments.name: type
arguments.desc: Tile in the particle texture atlas (0-15)

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Smoke particle
ParticleTile(0)

--Fire particle
ParticleTile(5)

functions.name: ParticleColor
functions.info: Set particle color to either constant (three arguments) or linear interpolation (six arguments)
functions.example:
--Constant red
ParticleColor(1,0,0)

--Animating from yellow to red
ParticleColor(1,1,0, 1,0,0)

functions.name: ParticleRadius

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info: Set the particle radius. Max radius for smoke particles is 1.0.
functions.example:
--Constant radius 0.4 meters
ParticleRadius(0.4)

--Interpolate from small to large
ParticleRadius(0.1, 0.7)

functions.name: ParticleAlpha

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info: Set the particle alpha (opacity).
functions.example:
--Interpolate from opaque to transparent
ParticleAlpha(1.0, 0.0)

functions.name: ParticleGravity

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info: Set particle gravity. It will be applied along the world Y axis. A negative value will move the particle downwards.
functions.example:
--Move particles slowly upwards
ParticleGravity(2)

functions.name: ParticleDrag

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info:
Particle drag will slow down fast moving particles. It's implemented slightly different for
smoke and plain particles. Drag must be positive, and usually look good between zero and one.
functions.example:
--Slow down fast moving particles
ParticleDrag(0.5)

functions.name: ParticleEmissive

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info: Draw particle as emissive (glow in the dark). This is useful for fire and embers.
functions.example:
--Highly emissive at start, not emissive at end
ParticleEmissive(5, 0)

functions.name: ParticleRotation

arguments.name: r0
arguments.desc: Rotation speed in radians per second.

arguments.name: r1
arguments.desc: End rotation speed in radians per second.

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info: Makes the particle rotate. Positive values is counter-clockwise rotation.
functions.example:
--Rotate fast at start and slow at end
ParticleRotation(10, 1)

functions.name: ParticleStretch

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info:
Stretch particle along with velocity. 0.0 means no stretching. 1.0 stretches with the particle motion over
one frame. Larger values stretches the particle even more.
functions.example:
--Stretch particle along direction of motion
ParticleStretch(1.0)

functions.name: ParticleSticky

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info: Make particle stick when in contact with objects. This can be used for friction.
functions.example:
--Make particles stick to objects
ParticleSticky(0.5)

functions.name: ParticleCollide

arguments.name: interpolation
arguments.desc: Interpolation method: linear, smooth, easein, easeout or constant. Default is linear.

arguments.name: fadein
arguments.desc: Fade in between t=0 and t=fadein. Default is zero.

arguments.name: fadeout
arguments.desc: Fade out between t=fadeout and t=1. Default is one.

functions.info:
Control particle collisions. A value of zero means that collisions are ignored. One means full collision.
It is sometimes useful to animate this value from zero to one in order to not collide with objects around
the emitter.
functions.example:
--Disable collisions
ParticleCollide(0)

--Enable collisions over time
ParticleCollide(0, 1)

--Ramp up collisions very quickly, only skipping the first 5% of lifetime
ParticleCollide(1, 1, "constant", 0.05)

functions.name: ParticleFlags
functions.info:
Set particle bitmask. The value 256 means fire extinguishing particles and is currently the only 
flag in use. There might be support for custom flags and queries in the future.
functions.example:
--Fire extinguishing particle
ParticleFlags(256)
SpawnParticle(...)

functions.name: SpawnParticle
functions.info:
Spawn particle using the previously set up particle state. You can call this multiple times
using the same particle state, but with different position, velocity and lifetime. You can
also modify individual properties in the particle state in between calls to to this function.
functions.example:
ParticleReset()
ParticleType("smoke")
ParticleColor(0.7, 0.6, 0.5)
--Spawn particle at world origo with upwards velocity and a lifetime of ten seconds
SpawnParticle(Vec(0, 0, 0), Vec(0, 1, 0), 10.0)

api.desc: The spawn API can be used to add entities into the existing scenes. You can spawn existing prefab XML files or generate XML and pass it in as a lua string.

functions.name: Spawn

arguments.name: allowStatic
arguments.desc: Allow spawning static shapes and bodies (default false)

arguments.name: jointExisting
arguments.desc: Allow joints to connect to existing scene geometry (default false)

return.name: entities
return.desc: Indexed table with handles to all spawned entities

functions.info:
The first argument can be either a prefab XML file in your mod folder or a string with XML content. It is also 
possible to spawn prefabs from other mods, by using the mod id followed by colon, followed by the prefab path.
Spawning prefabs from other mods should be used with causion since the referenced mod might not be installed.
functions.example:
Spawn("MOD/prefab/mycar.xml", Transform(Vec(0, 5, 0)))
Spawn("<voxbox size='10 10 10' prop='true' material='wood'/>", Transform(Vec(0, 10, 0)))

api.desc: Functions of peripheral nature that doesn't fit in anywhere else

functions.name: Shoot

arguments.name: origin
arguments.desc: Origin in world space as vector

arguments.name: direction
arguments.desc: Unit length direction as world space vector

arguments.name: type
arguments.desc: Shot type, see description, default is "bullet"

functions.info:
Fire projectile. Type can be one of "bullet", "rocket", "gun" or "shotgun".
For backwards compatilbility, type also accept a number, where 1 is same as "rocket" and anything else "bullet"
Note that this function will only spawn the projectile, not make any sound
Also note that "bullet" and "rocket" are the only projectiles that can hurt the player.
functions.example: Shoot(Vec(0, 10, 0), Vec(0, 0, 1), "shotgun")

functions.name: Paint

arguments.name: origin
arguments.desc: Origin in world space as vector

arguments.name: type
arguments.desc: Paint type. Can be "explosion" or "spraycan". Default is spraycan.

arguments.name: probability
arguments.desc: Dithering probability between zero and one, default is 1.0

functions.info: Tint the color of objects within radius to either black or yellow.
functions.example: Paint(Vec(0, 10, 0), 0.5, "spraycan")

functions.name: MakeHole

arguments.name: r1
arguments.desc: Hole radius for medium materials. May not be bigger than r0. Default zero.

arguments.name: r2
arguments.desc: Hole radius for hard materials. May not be bigger than r1. Default zero.

arguments.name: silent
arguments.desc: Make hole without playing any break sounds.

return.name: count
return.desc: Number of voxels that was cut out. This will be zero if there were no changes to any shape.

functions.info:
Make a hole in the environment. Radius is given in meters. 
Soft materials: glass, foliage, dirt, wood, plaster and plastic. 
Medium materials: concrete, brick and weak metal. 
Hard materials: hard metal and hard masonry.
functions.example: MakeHole(pos, 1.2, 1.0)

functions.name: Explosion

arguments.name: pos
arguments.desc: Position in world space as vector

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: Explosion(Vec(0, 10, 0), 1)

functions.name: SpawnFire

arguments.name: pos
arguments.desc: Position in world space as vector

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: SpawnFire(Vec(0, 10, 0))

functions.name: GetFireCount

return.name: count
return.desc: Number of active fires in level

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local c = GetFireCount()

functions.name: QueryClosestFire

return.name: hit
return.desc: A fire was found within search distance

return.name: pos
return.desc: Position of closest fire

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local hit, pos = QueryClosestFire(GetPlayerTransform().pos, 5.0)
if hit then
	--There is a fire within 5 meters to the player. Mark it with a debug cross.
	DebugCross(pos)
end

functions.name: QueryAabbFireCount

return.name: count
return.desc: Number of active fires in bounding box

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local count = QueryAabbFireCount(Vec(0,0,0), Vec(10,10,10))

functions.name: RemoveAabbFires

return.name: count
return.desc: Number of fires removed

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local removedCount= RemoveAabbFires(Vec(0,0,0), Vec(10,10,10))

functions.name: GetCameraTransform

return.name: transform
return.desc: Current camera transform

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local t = GetCameraTransform()

functions.name: SetCameraTransform

arguments.name: fov
arguments.desc: Optional horizontal field of view in degrees (default: 90)

functions.info: Override current camera transform for this frame. Call continuously to keep overriding.
functions.example: SetCameraTransform(Transform(Vec(0, 10, 0), QuatEuler(0, 90, 0)))

functions.name: SetCameraFov

arguments.name: degrees
arguments.desc: Horizontal field of view in degrees (10-170)

functions.info: Override field of view for the next frame for all camera modes, except when explicitly set in SetCameraTransform

functions.name: SetCameraDof
functions.info: Override depth of field for the next frame for all camera modes. Depth of field will be used even if turned off in options.
functions.example:
--Set depth of field to 10 meters
SetCameraDof(10)

functions.name: PointLight
functions.info:
Add a temporary point light to the world for this frame. Call continuously
for a steady light.
functions.example:
--Pulsating, yellow light above world origo
local intensity = 3 + math.sin(GetTime())
PointLight(Vec(0, 5, 0), 1, 1, 0, intensity)

functions.name: SetTimeScale
functions.info:
Experimental. Scale time in order to make a slow-motion effect. Audio will
also be affected. Note that this will affect physics behavior and is not
intended for gameplay purposes. Calling this function will slow down time
for the next frame only. Call every frame from tick function to get steady
slow-motion.
functions.example:
--Slow down time when holding down a key
if InputDown('t') then
SetTimeScale(0.2)
end

functions.name: SetEnvironmentDefault
functions.info:
Reset the environment properties to default. This is often useful before 
setting up a custom environment.
functions.example: SetEnvironmentDefault()

functions.name: SetEnvironmentProperty
functions.info:
This function is used for manipulating the environment properties. The available properties are 
exactly the same as in the editor, except for "snowonground" which is not currently supported.
functions.example:
SetEnvironmentProperty("skybox", "cloudy.dds")
SetEnvironmentProperty("rain", 0.7)
SetEnvironmentProperty("fogcolor", 0.5, 0.5, 0.8)
SetEnvironmentProperty("nightlight", false)

functions.name: GetEnvironmentProperty
functions.def: value0, value1, value2, value3, value4 = GetEnvironmentProperty(name)

return.name: value0
return.desc: Property value (type depends on property)

return.name: value1
return.desc: Property value (only some properties)

return.name: value2
return.desc: Property value (only some properties)

return.name: value3
return.desc: Property value (only some properties)

return.name: value4
return.desc: Property value (only some properties)

functions.info:
This function is used for querying the current environment properties. The available properties are
exactly the same as in the editor.
functions.example:
local skyboxPath = GetEnvironmentProperty("skybox")
local rainValue = GetEnvironmentProperty("rain")
local r,g,b = GetEnvironmentProperty("fogcolor")
local enabled = GetEnvironmentProperty("nightlight")

functions.name: SetPostProcessingDefault
functions.info: Reset the post processing properties to default.
functions.example: SetPostProcessingDefault()

functions.name: SetPostProcessingProperty
functions.info:
This function is used for manipulating the post processing properties. The available properties are
exactly the same as in the editor.
functions.example:
--Sepia post processing
SetPostProcessingProperty("saturation", 0.4)
SetPostProcessingProperty("colorbalance", 1.3, 1.0, 0.7)

functions.name: GetPostProcessingProperty

return.name: value0
return.desc: Property value

return.name: value1
return.desc: Property value (only some properties)

return.name: value2
return.desc: Property value (only some properties)

functions.info:
This function is used for querying the current post processing properties. 
The available properties are exactly the same as in the editor.
functions.example:
local saturation = GetPostProcessingProperty("saturation")
local r,g,b = GetPostProcessingProperty("colorbalance")

functions.name: DrawLine
functions.info: Draw a 3D line. In contrast to DebugLine, it will not show behind objects. Default color is white.
functions.example:
--Draw white debug line
DrawLine(Vec(0, 0, 0), Vec(-10, 5, -10))

--Draw red debug line
DrawLine(Vec(0, 0, 0), Vec(10, 5, 10), 1, 0, 0)

functions.name: DebugLine
functions.info: Draw a 3D debug overlay line in the world. Default color is white.
functions.example:
--Draw white debug line
DebugLine(Vec(0, 0, 0), Vec(-10, 5, -10))

--Draw red debug line
DebugLine(Vec(0, 0, 0), Vec(10, 5, 10), 1, 0, 0)

functions.name: DebugCross
functions.info: Draw a debug cross in the world to highlight a location. Default color is white.
functions.example: DebugCross(Vec(10, 5, 5))

functions.name: DebugWatch
functions.info:
Show a named valued on screen for debug purposes.
Up to 32 values can be shown simultaneously. Values updated the current
frame are drawn opaque. Old values are drawn transparent in white.
The function will also recognize vectors, quaternions and transforms as
second argument and convert them to strings automatically.
functions.example:
local t = 5
DebugWatch("time", t)

functions.name: DebugPrint
functions.info: Display message on screen. The last 20 lines are displayed.
functions.example: DebugPrint("time")

api.desc: The user interface functions are used for drawing interactive 2D graphics and can only be called from the draw function of a script. The ui functions are designed with the immediate mode gui paradigm in mind and uses a cursor and state stack. Pushing and popping the stack is cheap and designed to be called often.

functions.name: UiMakeInteractive
functions.info:
Calling this function will disable game input, bring up the mouse pointer
and allow Ui interaction with the calling script without pausing the game.
This can be useful to make interactive user interfaces from scripts while
the game is running. Call this continuously every frame as long as Ui 
interaction is desired.
functions.example: UiMakeInteractive()

functions.name: UiPush
functions.info:
Push state onto stack. This is used in combination with UiPop to
remember a state and restore to that state later.
functions.example:
UiColor(1,0,0)
UiText("Red")
UiPush()
	UiColor(0,1,0)
	UiText("Green")
UiPop()
UiText("Red")

functions.name: UiPop
functions.info:
Pop state from stack and make it the current one. This is used in
combination with UiPush to remember a previous state and go back to
it later.
functions.example:
UiColor(1,0,0)
UiText("Red")
UiPush()
	UiColor(0,1,0)
	UiText("Green")
UiPop()
UiText("Red")

functions.name: UiWidth

return.name: width
return.desc: Width of draw context

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local w = UiWidth()

functions.name: UiHeight

return.name: height
return.desc: Height of draw context

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local h = UiHeight()

functions.name: UiCenter

return.name: center
return.desc: Half width of draw context

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local c = UiCenter()
--Same as 
local c = UiWidth()/2

functions.name: UiMiddle

return.name: middle
return.desc: Half height of draw context

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
local m = UiMiddle()
--Same as
local m = UiHeight()/2

functions.name: UiColor
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Set color yellow
UiColor(1,1,0)

functions.name: UiColorFilter
functions.info: Color filter, multiplied to all future colors in this scope
functions.example:
UiPush()
	--Draw menu in transparent, yellow color tint
	UiColorFilter(1, 1, 0, 0.5)
	drawMenu()
UiPop()

functions.name: UiTranslate
functions.info: Translate cursor
functions.example:
UiPush()
	UiTranslate(100, 0)
	UiText("Indented")
UiPop()

functions.name: UiRotate
functions.info: Rotate cursor
functions.example:
UiPush()
	UiRotate(45)
	UiText("Rotated")
UiPop()

functions.name: UiScale

arguments.name: y
arguments.desc: Y component. Default value is x.

functions.info: Scale cursor either uniformly (one argument) or non-uniformly (two arguments)
functions.example:
UiPush()
	UiScale(2)
	UiText("Double size")
UiPop()

functions.name: UiWindow

arguments.name: clip
arguments.desc: Clip content outside window. Default is false.

arguments.name: inherit
arguments.desc: Inherit current clip region (for nested clip regions)

functions.info:
Set up new bounds. Calls to UiWidth, UiHeight, UiCenter and UiMiddle
will operate in the context of the window size. 
If clip is set to true, contents of window will be clipped to 
bounds (only works properly for non-rotated windows).
functions.example:
UiPush()
	UiWindow(400, 200)
	local w = UiWidth()
	--w is now 400
UiPop()

functions.name: UiSafeMargins

return.name: x0
return.desc: Left

return.name: y0
return.desc: Top

return.name: x1
return.desc: Right

return.name: y1
return.desc: Bottom

functions.info:
Return a safe drawing area that will always be visible regardless of
display aspect ratio. The safe drawing area will always be 1920 by 1080
in size. This is useful for setting up a fixed size UI.
functions.example:
function draw()
	local x0, y0, x1, y1 = UiSafeMargins()
	UiTranslate(x0, y0)
	UiWindow(x1-x0, y1-y0, true)
	--The drawing area is now 1920 by 1080 in the center of screen
	drawMenu()
end

functions.name: UiAlign
functions.info:
The alignment determines how content is aligned with respect to the
cursor.

Alignment  Description
left	 Horizontally align to the leftright	 Horizontally align to the rightcenter	 Horizontally align to the centertop		 Vertically align to the topbottom	 Veritcally align to the bottommiddle	 Vertically align to the middle
functions.example:
UiAlign("left")
UiText("Aligned left at baseline")

UiAlign("center middle")
UiText("Fully centered")

functions.name: UiModalBegin
functions.info:
Disable input for everything, except what's between UiModalBegin and UiModalEnd 
(or if modal state is popped)
functions.example:
UiModalBegin()
if UiTextButton("Okay") then
	--All other interactive ui elements except this one are disabled
end
UiModalEnd()

--This is also okay
UiPush()
	UiModalBegin()
	if UiTextButton("Okay") then
		--All other interactive ui elements except this one are disabled
	end
UiPop()
--No longer modal

functions.name: UiModalEnd
functions.info:
Disable input for everything, except what's between UiModalBegin and UiModalEnd
Calling this function is optional. Modality is part of the current state and will
be lost if modal state is popped.
functions.example:
UiModalBegin()
if UiTextButton("Okay") then
	--All other interactive ui elements except this one are disabled
end
UiModalEnd()

functions.name: UiDisableInput
functions.info: Disable input
functions.example:
UiPush()
	UiDisableInput()
	if UiTextButton("Okay") then
		--Will never happen
	end
UiPop()

functions.name: UiEnableInput
functions.info: Enable input that has been previously disabled
functions.example:
UiDisableInput()
if UiTextButton("Okay") then
	--Will never happen
end

UiEnableInput()
if UiTextButton("Okay") then
	--This can happen
end

functions.name: UiReceivesInput

return.name: receives
return.desc: True if current context receives input

functions.info:
This function will check current state receives input. This is the case 
if input is not explicitly disabled with (with UiDisableInput) and no other
state is currently modal (with UiModalBegin). Input functions and UI
elements already do this check internally, but it can sometimes be useful 
to read the input state manually to trigger things in the UI.
functions.example:
if UiReceivesInput() then
	highlightItemAtMousePointer()
end

functions.name: UiGetMousePos

return.name: x
return.desc: X coordinate

return.name: y
return.desc: Y coordinate

functions.info: Get mouse pointer position relative to the cursor
functions.example: local x, y = UiGetMousePos()

functions.name: UiIsMouseInRect

return.name: inside
return.desc: True if mouse pointer is within rectangle

functions.info:
Check if mouse pointer is within rectangle. Note that this function respects
alignment.
functions.example:
if UiIsMouseInRect(100, 100) then
	-- mouse pointer is in rectangle
end

functions.name: UiWorldToPixel

return.name: x
return.desc: X coordinate

return.name: y
return.desc: Y coordinate

return.name: distance
return.desc: Distance to point

functions.info:
Convert world space position to user interface X and Y coordinate relative
to the cursor. The distance is in meters and positive if in front of camera,
negative otherwise.
functions.example:
local x, y, dist = UiWorldToPixel(point)
if dist > 0 then
UiTranslate(x, y)
UiText("Label")
end

functions.name: UiPixelToWorld

return.name: direction
return.desc: 3D world direction as vector

functions.info:
Convert X and Y UI coordinate to a world direction, as seen from current camera.
This can be used to raycast into the scene from the mouse pointer position.
functions.example:
UiMakeInteractive()
local x, y = UiGetMousePos()
local dir = UiPixelToWorld(x, y)
local pos = GetCameraTransform().pos
local hit, dist = QueryRaycast(pos, dir, 100)
if hit then
	DebugPrint("hit distance: " .. dist)
end

functions.name: UiBlur
functions.info: Perform a gaussian blur on current screen content
functions.example:
UiBlur(1.0)
drawMenu()

functions.name: UiFont
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
UiFont("bold.ttf", 24)
UiText("Hello")

functions.name: UiFontHeight

return.name: size
return.desc: Font size

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local h = UiFontHeight()

functions.name: UiText

arguments.name: move
arguments.desc: Automatically move cursor vertically. Default false.

return.name: w
return.desc: Width of text

return.name: h
return.desc: Height of text

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
UiFont("bold.ttf", 24)
UiText("Hello")

...

--Automatically advance cursor
UiText("First line", true)
UiText("Second line", true)

functions.name: UiGetTextSize

return.name: w
return.desc: Width of text

return.name: h
return.desc: Height of text

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: local w, h = UiGetTextSize("Some text")

functions.name: UiWordWrap
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
UiWordWrap(200)
UiText("Some really long text that will get wrapped into several lines")

functions.name: UiTextOutline
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Black outline, standard thickness
UiTextOutline(0,0,0,1)
UiText("Text with outline")

functions.name: UiTextShadow
functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Black drop shadow, 50% transparent, distance 2
UiTextShadow(0, 0, 0, 0.5, 2.0)
UiText("Text with drop shadow")

functions.name: UiRect
functions.info: Draw solid rectangle at cursor position
functions.example:
--Draw full-screen black rectangle
UiColor(0, 0, 0)
UiRect(UiWidth(), UiHeight())

--Draw smaller, red, rotating rectangle in center of screen
UiPush()
	UiColor(1, 0, 0)
	UiTranslate(UiCenter(), UiMiddle())
	UiRotate(GetTime())
	UiAlign("center middle")
	UiRect(100, 100)
UiPop()

functions.name: UiImage

arguments.name: path
arguments.desc: Path to image (PNG or JPG format)

arguments.name: x1
arguments.desc: Upper x coordinate (default is image width)

arguments.name: y1
arguments.desc: Upper y coordinate (default is image height)

return.name: w
return.desc: Width of drawn image

return.name: h
return.desc: Height of drawn image

functions.info:
Draw image at cursor position. If x0, y0, x1, y1 is provided a cropped version
will be drawn in that coordinate range.
functions.example:
--Draw image in center of screen
UiPush()
	UiTranslate(UiCenter(), UiMiddle())
	UiAlign("center middle")
	UiImage("test.png")
UiPop()

functions.name: UiGetImageSize

arguments.name: path
arguments.desc: Path to image (PNG or JPG format)

return.name: w
return.desc: Image width

return.name: h
return.desc: Image height

functions.info: Get image size
functions.example: local w,h = UiGetImageSize("test.png")

functions.name: UiImageBox

arguments.name: path
arguments.desc: Path to image (PNG or JPG format)

functions.info:
Draw 9-slice image at cursor position. Width should be at least 2*borderWidth.
Height should be at least 2*borderHeight.
functions.example: UiImageBox("menu-frame.png", 200, 200, 10, 10)

functions.name: UiSound
functions.info: UI sounds are not affected by acoustics simulation. Use LoadSound / PlaySound for that.
functions.example: UiSound("click.ogg")

functions.name: UiSoundLoop

arguments.name: path
arguments.desc: Path to looping sound file (OGG format)

functions.info:
Call this continuously to keep playing loop. 
UI sounds are not affected by acoustics simulation. Use LoadLoop / PlayLoop for that.
functions.example:
if animating then
	UiSoundLoop("screech.ogg")
end

functions.name: UiMute
functions.info:
Mute game audio and optionally music for the next frame. Call
continuously to stay muted.
functions.example:
if menuOpen then
	UiMute(1.0)
end

functions.name: UiButtonImageBox

arguments.name: path
arguments.desc: Path to image (PNG or JPG format)

functions.info: Set up 9-slice image to be used as background for buttons.
functions.example:
UiButtonImageBox("button-9slice.png", 10, 10)
if UiTextButton("Test") then
	...
end

functions.name: UiButtonHoverColor
functions.info: Button color filter when hovering mouse pointer.
functions.example:
UiButtonHoverColor(1, 0, 0)
if UiTextButton("Test") then
	...
end

functions.name: UiButtonPressColor
functions.info: Button color filter when pressing down.
functions.example:
UiButtonPressColor(0, 1, 0)
if UiTextButton("Test") then
	...
end

functions.name: UiButtonPressDist
functions.info: The button offset when being pressed
functions.example:
UiButtonPressDistance(4)
if UiTextButton("Test") then
	...
end

functions.name: UiTextButton

return.name: pressed
return.desc: True if user clicked button

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if UiTextButton("Test") then
	...
end

functions.name: UiImageButton

return.name: pressed
return.desc: True if user clicked button

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if UiImageButton("image.png") then
	...
end

functions.name: UiBlankButton

return.name: pressed
return.desc: True if user clicked button

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
if UiBlankButton(30, 30) then
	...
end

functions.name: UiSlider
functions.def: value, done = UiSlider(path, axis, current, min, max)

return.name: value
return.desc: New value, same as current if not changed

return.name: done
return.desc: True if user is finished changing (released slider)

functions.info: No Description
functions.example: value = UiSlider("dot.png", "x", value, 0, 100)

functions.name: UiGetScreen

return.name: handle
return.desc: Handle to the screen running this script or zero if none.

functions.info: No Description
functions.example:
--Turn off screen running current script
screen = UiGetScreen()
SetScreenEnabled(screen, false)
